comments.body: I would think plugins would need a qualified naming syntax to avoid collisions and to not block our ability to use a kind or resource name in the future.

Hrm, I'm not sure I follow, they are in a qualified name under the `custom` path.

The name of the object is implicitly `custom.<type-name>`

They're always going to come in under a different RESTful path, so even if they have the same name as a type that we want to have, then we will still be able to tell the difference between a built-in object and a plugin object.
I didn't catch the custom prefix being before namespace.  Thought that meant whatever the API root would have been.  Sorry for confusion.
That being said, I think it should be after namespace.

The trouble is that currently the namespace comes after the `/api/v1` part of the path and

`/api/v1/namespaces/<namespace-name>/custom/<type-name>/<version-name>/<object-name>`

since `v1` actually has no relevance to this custom type.

Given the current URL scheme of `$group/$version/namespaces/$ns/$kind/$name`, I think this HAS to be `/custom/$version/namespaces/$ns/$kind/$name` which is neither what Brendan wrote nor what Derek wrote.

Brendan, what you wrote sets bad precedent - either plugins are sort of second-class and therefore get different structure or else it suggests that every object should have it's own version numbers and we should migrate all of /api towards that.

`/custom/$version/namespaces/$ns/$kind/$name` acts as a special case of api-groups, which (when completed) could become another parameter of the schema.
I agree with @thockin. We should be exploiting apigroups.

comments.body: Presumably we want ThirdPartyResource to be available to all namespaces.

Not sure what you mean by this...

Yes, we want to be able to have instances of a particular `ThirdPartyResource` (e.g. an instance of a  `CronTab` resource from below) in different namespaces.

But I don't think that we want to allow users to declare their `ThirdPartyResource` instances themselves inside of a namespace.  The reason for this is that it becomes quite difficult to validate the `kind` information for a particular resource, unless we fold the namespace into the `kind` field, and if we do that, we're really just creating additional depth in the api groups and versions that is complicated and unnecessary.
